In one family of algorithms ([4], [ 7 ]), each pixel p consults, perhaps repeatedly, with other pixels in a typically small neighborhood of p, and bases its updated transform value on those of its neighbors.

However, the lack of efficient algorithms for computing the Euclidean distance transform has led many researchers to define and use other metrics (such as city-block, chessboard or chamfer [8], [22], [4]), or approximations to the exact Euclidean distance transform [ 7 ], [4], [5], [22].While other metrics lend themselves to efficient algorithms, they do so at the expense of being dependent on the orientation of the coordinate system used ...

paperAbstract.text: This paper gives approximation algorithms of solving the following motion planning problem: Given a set of polyhedral obstacles and points s and t, find a shortest path from s to t that avoids the obstacles. The paths found by the algorithms are piecewise linear, and the length of a path is the sum of the lengths of the line segments making up the path. Approximation algorithms will be given for versions of this problem in the plane and in three-dimensional space. The algorithms return an &egr;-short path, that is, a path with length within (1 + &egr;) of shortest. Let n be the total number of faces of the polyhedral obstacles, and &egr; a given value satisfying &Ogr; < &egr; ≤ &pgr;. The algorithm for the planar case requires &Ogr;(n log n)/&egr; time to build a data structure of size &Ogr;(n/&egr;). Given points s and t, and &egr;-short path from s to t can be found with the use of the data structure in time &Ogr;(n/&egr; + n log n). The data structure is associated with a new variety of Voronoi diagram. Given obstacles S ⊂ &Egr;3 and points s, t &egr; E3, an &egr;-short path between s and t can be found in &Ogr;(n2&lgr;(n) log(n/&egr;)/&egr;4 + n2 lognp log(n logp)) time, where p is the ratio of the length of the longest obstacle edge to the distance between s to t. The function &lgr;(n) = &agr;(n)&Ogr;(&agr;(n)&Ogr;(1)), where the &agr;(n) is a form of inverse of Ackermann's function. For log(1/&egr;) and log p that are &Ogr;(log n), this bound is &Ogr;(log n2(n)&lgr;(n)/&egr;4).

title.text: Approximation algorithms for shortest path motion planning

tldr.text: This paper gives approximation algorithms of solving the following motion planning problem: Given a set of polyhedral obstacles and points s and t, find a shortest path from s to t that avoids the obstacles.

paperAbstract.text: This correspondence defines a signed distance, called ``internal concavity,'' on paths of the Voronoi diagram of a dot pattern. An algorithm using internal concavity to segment dot patterns is described. The segmentation algorithm produces subsets of the Dirichlet tessellation (Delaunay triangulation) of the dot pattern.

title.text: Segmenting Dot Patterns by Voronoi Diagram Concavity

tldr.text: An algorithm using internal concavity to segment dot patterns is described, which produces subsets of the Dirichlet tessellation (Delaunay triangulation) of the dot pattern.

venue.text: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence

context.text: A familiar approach ([ 15 ]) to the construction of Voronoi diagrams is divide and conquer: (linearly) separate the sites into two subsets, recursively construct the Voronoi diagrams of the subsets, and “merge” the resulting diagrams into the Voronoi diagram of the full set.
In fact, these bounds are realized by familiar algorithms for constructing and querying Voronoi diagrams ([ 15 ]).
In fact, it is well known ([ 15 ]) that linear algorithms do not exist for determining, for each of ai

paperAbstract.text: From the reviews: "This book offers a coherent treatment, at the graduate textbook level, of the field that has come to be known in the last decade or so as computational geometry...The book is well organized and lucidly written; a timely contribution by two founders of the field. It clearly demonstrates that computational geometry in the plane is now a fairly well-understood branch of computer science and mathematics. It also points the way to the solution of the more challenging problems in dimensions higher than two."

tldr.text: This book offers a coherent treatment, at the graduate textbook level, of the field that has come to be known in the last decade or so as computational geometry.

paperAbstract.text: The relative merits of performing local operations on ~ digitized picture in parallel or sequentially are discussed. Sequential local operations are described which l~bel the connected components of a given subset of the picture and compute u "distance" from every picture element to the subset. In terms of the "distance" function, ~ "skeleton" subset is defined which, in a certain sense, minimally determines the original subset. Some applications of the connected component and distance functions are also presented.

title.text: Sequential Operations in Digital Picture Processing

tldr.text: The relative merits of performing local operations on ~ digitized picture in parallel or sequentially are discussed and some applications of the connected component and distance functions are presented.

title.text: Distance transforms: Properties and machine vision applications
